comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
It must have been 1948 for me, and it's been downhill ever since!
I bet his Dad was an Italian, running the ice-cream shop.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Maybe some help from Waterford peeps? No Fortes in Waterford in 1911 census. In fact, only 44 in the whole of Ireland - all in the north - Antrim and Down, except for one in Meath and one in Cork...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Carol may I ask the process you use to digitise the different types of media you come across in the different collections. D

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Alfred certainly looks very Italian and what a well dressed little boy he is. I wonder if his family were recent arrivals in Ireland?

comment.author: 24474458@N08
comment._content: Wonderful Photo...but maybe I am wrong...I think it could be later than 1920s...please correct me if I am.... :) Vera xx

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Of course you may ask! Staff in our digital studio do all the hard work. I just get to enjoy the fruits of their labour, and pass on to you guys here. Just to give you an example, the Lawrence Collection glass negatives like this one that I upload here are scanned at 1200dpi on an Epson Expression 10000XL scanner. I just reduce the size using Photoshop so that they're not quite so gargantuan memory-wise...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: My late father in law often mentioned the Forte family who were in the fish and chip business in Waterford up to the second WW.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  Go raibh maith agat .

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04/] a friend on Facebook just commented that he remembers a Mr Forte being mentioned in the context of him being an employer, he thinks he was a restaurant owner maybe circa 1940's.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Look what I found, chaps: "Uncle Charlie moved to Ireland in the late 1930s and married Emilia Magliocco, also from Mortale. They had a restaurant in Waterford and a beach cafe at nearby Tramore until the late 1940s, when they returned to Brighton. They had four children, Alfonso, Filomena, Frederick and Michael" from the Brighton Fortes site. So our "Alfred" above could actually be Frederick?? Changing posited date to 1945?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] A nice find Carol, thanks. Incidentally one of my aunts married into an Italian family, Delicato, who had the Venetian Cafe in Waterford for many years.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: I hope the family had a better life in Ireland, rather than being interned as enemy aliens on the Isle of Man during WW2. I cannot find any births in Britain on FreeBMD

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The second I saw the photo I thought Italian or Spanish, that suit is so distinctive.  There are lots of Forte's around Dublin these days but they may not have been there in the early years of the last century.  I always thought they came after WWI?  In limerick we had a family living locally named DiVito, they were very good natured and hard working.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: If the lad was named Alfonso, he might well have gone by Alfred "as gaeilge".

comment._content: Great portrait.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: They are, of course, part of the famous Italian Forte family (which also includes "Hotel Inspector" Alex Polizzi) which now operate luxury hotels throughout Europe.
